sentence: Per-o se nije sjeti-o drug-og put-a
glosses_en: PN-NOM.SG REFL NEG.be.PRS.3SG remember-PART.PERF.M.SG other-GEN.SG.M road-GEN.SG
comms_internal: REFL. Alternative is the construction “Pero je zaboravio na drugi put” with the NOM_naACC pattern, but arguably it is slightly less natural. A still further alternative is biclausal construction with the predicate smetnuti s uma: “Pero je smetnuo s uma da postoji drugi put.” The same verb “se sjetio” is used with the NOM_GEN pattern even without negation.

It is not entirely clear how the preposition “o” in this construction entered the language. It may be a calque from New Latin “dependere de” (in Classical Latin, the usual construction was “pendere ex”).

sentence: Per-o se upozna-o s Miš-om prije godin-u dan-a
glosses_en: PN-NOM.SG REFL get.to.know-PART.PERF.M.SG with PN-INS.SG before year-ACC.SG day-GEN.PL
back_translation_en: ‘Pero got to know Mišo a year ago.’
comms_internal: REFL. Alternative is the transitive construction “Pero je upoznao Mišu prije godinu dana”. The actual construction rather denotes entering the state of being acquainted, whereas its alternative is more about some new experience.

sentence: moj-a košulj-a je drukčij-a od tvoj-e
glosses_en: my-NOM.SG.F shirt-NOM.SG be.PRS.3SG different-NOM.SG.F from your-GEN.SG.F

smrde is a regular 3PL form. Alternative is “Ruke mi smrde na benzin” with the NOM_naACC pattern and the same verb. A still further alternative is “Ruke mi smrde od benzina” with the NOM_odGEN pattern. According to Mislav, the difference is that the NOM_naACC denotes the type of smell, NOM_poLOC denotes a mixture of Stimulus and Causer, and NOM_odGEN denotes a Causer only. In some dialects, the Instrumental case is also an option.
Alternative is "Pero je prešao preko ceste", but this would be more appropriate if e.g. there is an animal crossing the street.
In the Standard Croatian, there is a contrast between verbs “(o/ros)topiti” (to dissolve) and “(ras)taliti” (to melt), which is absent in at least some dialects. Anyway, the construction is the same.

Alternative is the transitive construction “Pero je ispustio čašu (iz ruke)”, which is slightly less natural and less directly corresponds to the meaning of the stimulus sentence in Russian.

The verb “rukovoditi” is not possible in colloquial language. It is probably possible in the Standard language, but sounds archaic. The construction would be "upravljati", it would imply that Pero is a non-official boss.
Same as 56. An alternative is “Pero tuguje za Marijom” but this may be a less direct equivalent of the stimulus sentence in Russian.

Same verb as in 73, different construction. Alternatives are constructions like “Pero dolazi poslije Miše” with the pattern NOM_poslijeGEN” or “Pero slijedi za Mišom” with the pattern NOM_zaINS. However, the latter verb is not typical of everyday communication. Finally, there is also the transitive construction with "pratiti", Pero prati Mišu, which would mean something like 'escort, begleiten'.
Alternative is the ame construction with the verb "sići", cf. "Per-o je siša-o s konj-a"
